talk.author: did:plc:wvvrly43n3a5q2heaoen3qxc
talk.utter: Yes! I've been giving meal worms to a pair of crows and their fledgling around my house for several months and they know my schedule quite well. I always leave the food in a dedicated spot and say the same thing when I see them. I think the adults are teaching the fledgling that I prefer quiet.

talk.author: did:plc:tbqqvyv6pjjww44glrmycaxl
talk.utter: Interesting! I've tried to teach the crows "ssshhhh" but have had no success.

talk.author: did:plc:wvvrly43n3a5q2heaoen3qxc
talk.utter: I give extra snacks when they are quiet. Because I only had the two adults for a while it's much easier since they are usually quiet. If they make noise, I am slower to hand out the treats.

talk.author: did:plc:wvvrly43n3a5q2heaoen3qxc
talk.utter: I give extra snacks when they are quiet. Because I only had the two adults for a while it's much easier since they are usually quiet. If they make noise, I am slower to hand out the treats.

talk.author: did:plc:2obtldrf6h4jyg4ttea63nbd
talk.utter: Yeah this is same for me essentially though I see it as giving less treats for being loud but it is essentially the same thing ðŸ˜‚

talk.author: did:plc:wvvrly43n3a5q2heaoen3qxc
talk.utter: Yup. If they make noise, I make an exaggerated "I am distracted by you" body motion where I turn to look at them for a moment, and that takes time away from me walking to the sealed container where all of the different bird treats are. But they know now that if they're polite, I go fast.
